concept.title: Links to non-DITA resources
concept.shortdesc: Cross-references can be used to link from within DITA topics to non-DITA resources, such as Web URLs, e-mail addresses, and documents stored on file servers. The scope and format attributes of the cross-reference are used to define the nature of the linked resource, and indirectly the way the link will behave.

conbody.p: The four most important attributes in the cross-reference (xref) element are href, type, scope and format.

When linking to non-DITA resources such as PDF files or Web addresses, the scope attribute describes whether the linked resource is treated as part of the DITA collection or external to it. This setting will ultimately determine how the HTML output code will be formed during the publishing process, and then how the browser will handle the link. The format attribute describes the type of resource being linked to.

The main scope attribute values are:
local
the resource forms part of the content collection (and will typically be opened in the current browser when it is output to a hypertext form)
external
the resource is managed separately to the content collection (and will typically be opened in a new browser or tab when it is output to a hypertext form)
conbody.note: The other valid scope attribute of peer is similar to local, but is used when the linked resource is not available at build time. It is only relevant when linking to DITA resources.
conbody.p:
The valid format attribute values for non-DITA resources are:
html
the non-DITA file format of the linked resource is HTML or XHTML
pdf
the non-DITA file format of the linked resource is PDF
txt
the non-DITA file format of the linked resource is plain text
file type
the three letter file extension of the non-DITA file format of the linked resource (for example, ppt and odt)

An example of the code for a local and an external cross-reference link is: <xref href="somefile.html" format="html" scope="local" /> <xref href="somefile.doc" format="doc" scope="external" /> <xref href="http://abc.com/intro.htm" format="html" scope="external" />

section.title: Rationale

lq.reftitle: Deborah Pickett, Yahoo! DITA Users Group

section.lq: georgerioux wrote: From what I can gather from reading the spec (which explicitly mentions linking to .txt files), you should be able to do this by setting the correct format (e.g., doc) and scope (e.g., peer) attributes, but when I add the xref in my source the link in the HTML output does not work. (I've tried several different combinations of scope and format.) Try using scope="external" and copying the *.doc file manually to the output area after the build has finished. (scope="peer" is almost never what you want. It is for a very specific use that doesn't include what you are trying to do.)

lq.reftitle: Deborah Pickett, Yahoo! DITA Users Group
lq.p: On 2010-03-18 05.38, mt_si_dad wrote: > <xref href="mailto:name@domain. com">Click to send e-mail</xref>
Yes, that looks good. I'd also recommend adding scope="external" so that the build knows not to try to follow the link.

lq.reftitle: Eliot Kimber, Yahoo! DITA Users Group

section.lq: You need to add scope="external" ( as you would for any reference to things that are outside of your DITA content set). You may need to also say format="email" or something but that probably shouldn't be necessary -- most processors should just pass an external URI straight through to the output.
